content.description: Layback overhang (though other options exist if dry), then climb crack to tree with rap anchor.
content.location: 10 feet right of Five Start Crack at an overhang with a crack above it that goes to the top.  Often dirty/wet.

content.description: Every crag deserves a legitimate easy, "warm up" pitch, and this is it for Lost T.  Cleaned and led while we waited for the cliff to dry after a very wet night.
content.location: Located 30 feet right of Fat People, this is the right-most line on the cliff.  Look for a blocky vague depression with a 2x3 ft projecting block at the top of the cliff.  The route climbs over this block (crux), but you can bypass it on the right in which case the route is 5.3.

content.description: Just to the right of Emily doesn't have a clue and Flavor of the Day is a wide crack that Rob Upton cleaned in June of 2016. Please try it.

climbs.name: Teriyaki Hairpiece
climbs.fa: ACB Jul 31, 2012 Jim Lawyer and Jeremy Haas

content.description: Go up mossy holds to the obvious crack and flared section. Stay in the crack or head slightly right to the crimpy face, finishing on the crack to the top. No permanent anchor but its possible to easily sling the tree on the top and walkoff or rap from a nearby route with a fixed anchor
content.location: Leftmost crack on the Lost T wall

content.description: Up to left facing corner, then step left/traverse to horizontal below overlap.  Up to parallel seams and to the top.
content.location: At a shallow left facing corner 50 right of the chimney (12 feet right of CB Love Grannys).

climbs.name: Sumo Wrestlers are Hard To Kidnap

content.description: From right side of boulder pile move up to ledge, then follow crack systems to ledges and bolts to the top.
content.protection: Has been bolted (previously R, unsure if bolting resolved all protection issues - hopefully someone who climbed it recently will chime in).  May want additional gear.
content.location: 40 feet right of Flavor of the Day, at blocks with crack systems above.

content.description: Up groove to bolts.  Then climb (small cams) to anchor.
content.location: At a groove several feet right of Freckles with No Lipstick, and left of The Keyhole's obvious left facing corner.

content.description: One of two sport routes at this cliff. Wonderful climbing that requires good footwork. At times you can grab a hold on one of the neighboring routes, but whatevs…stay true to the line for the best climbing. Also, it’s one of the first routes to dry on the cliff, and sometimes is the only dry route.Stick clip, and be careful making the second clip. (If you’re super concerned about this clip, there is gear, or you could always stick-clip bolt #2.Climb face to seam, up this, then up more face past a couple horizontals to a fixed anchor.
content.location: On the face between Little Kisses and Five Star Crack.

content.description: Starts about 10 ft left of Coach and Mary and goes over the roof at start.  This is the route the bolt was chopped on.  Bolt has been replaced.  Stick clip the bolt, pull over roof and continue up crack.  Crux is 3/4 of the way up and crack runs out and you have to move about 3 ft right into adjacent crack.  Very nice route.
content.protection: Gear up to about 1 inch.  Anchors at top.
content.location: Look for the roof left of Coach and Mary.

content.description: Climb to bolt (crux) then up crack to the bolted anchor.
content.location: Middle of the cliff, below a bolt 15 feet up and a long crack that goes to the top.

content.description: Up face through bolts to overhang, step left and through overhang, then up and left to anchor.
content.location: Middle of the cliff at an obvious left facing corner, start ten feet left of corner.  [start in the corner is 5.9]

content.description: Up face (3 bolts) to horizontal crack, then up to pine tree belay/anchor.
content.location: Left side of wall, right of the chimney.

content.description: Climbs bolts up face/cracks to anchors.
content.location: 5 feet right (downhill) from Ten B at a face with seams and a bolt 12 feet up.

content.description:
Stick clip first bolt. Climb up a shallow corner to a jagged jug rail below the roof. Pull the roof (crux), then climb the arete to a fixed anchor. 

  The route is considerably more difficult for a short person.
content.location: At a boulder pile on the right end of the wall below a large roof.

content.description: Climb left of dead tree to gain crack, take this past many horizontals to the top anchor.
content.location: 20 feet right of Little Kisses at a hand crack.

content.description: Follow seam/crack.
content.location: Right of Keegan's 5.8 and slightly left of a pine tree.

content.description: Up ramp to right facing corner (tree), then take large crack in corner past the left side of the roof and to the fixed anchor.
content.location: At a boulder pile at the right end of the wall, below a large roof.

climbs.name: Dixie Normus
climbs.fa: Jeff Erickson, 2012; direct start added 2020 Jonathan Nickel

content.description: The beautiful finger cracks on the upper 3/4 of this climb were climbed by Erickson in 2012 by traversing in from the right after climbing the start of Wide Crack.  A direct start with three bolts was added in 2020, making the route an excellent independent line. Start by scrambling up 6' to the ledge below Wide Crack, move left on the ledge and stand up on a block.  Face climb up past a small overhang and right-facing corner, then follow bolts slightly left to the start of the crack.  Climb the outstanding finger crack up and a little left (almost to 5 Star Crack), then up and right, as the crack jogs right at several horizontals to a two bolt anchor with rings at the top of the cliff.
content.protection: The route can be safely led ground up (green Alien in the horizontal under the small overhang), but it is possible to use a long stick clip to clip the first bolt. After the three bolts, the route follows a remarkably consistent finger-sized crack to the anchor. Therefore, bring many finger-sized cams (blue and yellow Metolius, green and yellow Aliens, 0.2 - 0.4 Black Diamond). Triples in that range would be appropriate. The crack generally does not take nuts well. There is no need for any gear larger than a 0.75 Camalot, although there is an optional #4 Camalot placement in a horizontal 3/4 of the way up.
content.location: Just right of the large dead tree near the center of the cliff.

content.description: Start on neighboring route Wide Crack, then move out to the bolts that lead right into the dike, past a tree, and up a deep crack to the top.
content.location: Same as Wide Crack, traverses right above an overhang to a dike.

content.description: Climb up the alcove, up the hand crack to the ledge with a tree on it. Climb up blocky ledges until you reach the base of a hand crack on your right, and a thin seam with crimps on your left. Make a few moves up the right crack to place a piece of gear, then traverse left over on to the crimps of the left seam. Follow this past two horizontals and up the seam unit you reach a jug, top this and finish up an easy hand crack to the top.
content.protection: This line does not need bolts. The first ascent was done on all gear. Small cams, micro cams.
content.location: Start 15 feet left of Little Kisses, in an open book alcove below a hand crack that ends at a tree on a ledge 20 feet above. Start directly below the tree in the alcove.

content.description: This is a good route up a beautiful face, but it is only for the bold.  Start right of the bolt line for Keyhole at a left-facing corner.  Up the dirty corner to a point where it is obvious to step left and climb the crack.  About 2/3rds of the way up, the crack peters out (last gear for a while - load it up).  Make a move up and left to a jug, then make crux moves with poor feet to a horizontal with gear.  If you blow it here a 20+' fall is possible.  Up an easier crack to a slung tree.  At the time of this writing, the slings should probably be replaced.

Start at a small, slightly overhung ledge.  Then up a wide, deep, off-width crack.  Takes large gear up to #4.  The crack tops out at a small ledge from which you traverse left onto the face to gain the anchors.
content.location: Right end of cliffs.

content.description: Up face to first seam, then up to next left leaning seam to top.
content.location: 15 feet right of Expiration 66, below a left leaning seam that starts 8 feet up.

content.description: Tucked away above Chub Lake is this excellent cliff averaging 40-80 feet in height with high quality cracks.Mostly trad with added bolts, and a few bolted lines. Top ropes can be setup for most (if not all) routes.Important - Some routes with bolts are intended to be stick clipped to protect the opening moves.This area is well-documented in the Southern Adirondack Routes digital guidebook.
